shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच। धर्मक्षेत्रे कुरुक्षेत्रे समवेता युयुत्सवः। मामकाः पाण्डवाश्चैव किमकुर्वत सञ्जय॥
translation: Tell me, Sanjaya, what did my sons and the sons of Pandu do when they gathered on the sacred field of Kurukshetra, eager for battle?

shloka: सञ्जय उवाच। दृष्ट्वा तु पाण्डवानीकं व्यूढं दुर्योधनस्तदा। आचार्यमुपसङ्गम्य राजा वचनमब्रवीत्॥
translation: O King, when Duryodhana saw the Pandava army arrayed for battle, he approached his teacher and spoke these words:

shloka: पश्यैतां पाण्डुपुत्राणामाचार्य महतीं चमूम्। व्यूढां द्रुपदपुत्रेण तव शिष्येण धीमता॥
translation: Look, O Teacher, at this mighty army of the Pandavas, arranged by your own wise disciple, the son of Drupada.

shloka: अत्र शूरा महेष्वासा भीमार्जुनसमा युधि। युयुधानो विराटश्च द्रुपदश्च महारथः॥
translation: Here stand great warriors like Bhima and Arjuna—Yuyudhana, Virata, and Drupada, all unmatched in combat.

shloka: धृष्टकेतुश्चेकितानः काशिराजश्च वीर्यवान्। पुरुजित्कुन्तिभोजश्च शैब्यश्च नरपुङ्गवः॥
translation: See the heroic Drishtaketu, Chekitana, the king of Kashi, Purujit, Kuntibhoja, and Shaibya—the best of men.

shloka: युधामन्युश्च विक्रान्त उत्तमौजाश्च वीर्यवान्। सौभद्रो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्व एव महारथाः॥
translation: Behold the valiant Yudhamanyu, Uttamaujas, the son of Subhadra, and the sons of Draupadi—all masters of warfare.

shloka: अस्माकं तु विशिष्टा ये तान्निबोध द्विजोत्तम। नायका मम सैन्यस्य संज्ञार्थं तान्ब्रवीमि ते॥
translation: Now, O noble one, let me name the leaders of *my* army for your understanding.

shloka: भवान्भीष्मश्च कर्णश्च कृपश्च समितिञ्जयः। अश्वत्थामा विकर्णश्च सौमदत्तिस्तथैव च॥
translation: You, Bhishma, Karna, Kripa, Ashwatthama, Vikarna, and the son of Somadatta—all undefeatable.

shloka: अन्ये च बहवः शूरा मदर्थे त्यक्तजीविताः। नानाशस्त्रप्रहरणाः सर्वे युद्धविशारदाः॥
translation: Countless others stand ready to die for me, armed with every weapon, all expert in battle.

shloka: अपर्याप्तं तदस्माकं बलं भीष्माभिरक्षितम्। पर्याप्तं त्विदमेतेषां बलं भीमाभिरक्षितम्॥
translation: Our forces, guarded by Bhishma, are boundless—but theirs, protected by Bhima, are limited.

shloka: अयनेषु च सर्वेषु यथाभागमवस्थिताः। भीष्ममेवाभिरक्षन्तु भवन्तः सर्व एव हि॥
translation: Hold your positions! Focus all your strength on protecting Bhishma alone.

shloka: तस्य सञ्जनयन्हर्षं कुरुवृद्धः पितामहः। सिंहनादं विनद्योच्चैः शङ्खं दध्मौ प्रतापवान्॥
translation: To rally the troops, mighty Bhishma roared like a lion and blew his conch, shaking the battlefield.

shloka: ततः शङ्खाश्च भेर्यश्च पणवानकगोमुखाः। सहसैवाभ्यहन्यन्त स शब्दस्तुमुलोऽभवत्॥
translation: Then—conches, drums, trumpets! The sudden clash of sound was deafening.

shloka: ततः श्वेतैर्हयैर्युक्ते महति स्यन्दने स्थितौ। माधवः पाण्डवश्चैव दिव्यौ शङ्खौ प्रदध्मतुः॥
translation: Then Krishna and Arjuna, seated in their glorious chariot, blew their divine conches.

shloka: संजय उवाच। तं तथा कृपयाविष्टमश्रुपूर्णाकुलेक्षणम्। विषीदन्तमिदं वाक्यमुवाच मधुसूदनः॥
translation: Sanjaya said: Seeing Arjuna overwhelmed with pity, his eyes filled with tears, Krishna spoke these words to him.

shloka: श्रीभगवानुवाच। कुतस्त्वा कश्मलमिदं विषमे समुपस्थितम्। अनार्यजुष्टमस्वर्ग्यमकीर्तिकरमर्जुन॥
translation: The Lord said: O Arjuna, how has this delusion overcome you in this hour of crisis? It is unworthy of a noble mind, it bars the path to heaven, and it brings disgrace.

shloka: क्लैब्यं मा स्म गमः पार्थ नैतत्त्वय्युपपद्यते। क्षुद्रं हृदयदौर्बल्यं त्यक्त्वोत्तिष्ठ परंतप॥
translation: Do not yield to unmanliness, O Arjuna! It does not befit you. Shake off this petty weakness of heart and arise, O scorcher of foes!

shloka: अर्जुन उवाच। कथं भीष्ममहं संख्ये द्रोणं च मधुसूदन। इषुभिः प्रतियोत्स्यामि पूजार्हावरिसूदन॥
translation: Arjuna said: O Madhusudana, how can I fight against Bhishma and Drona with arrows when they deserve my worship?

shloka: गुरूनहत्वा हि महानुभावान् श्रेयो भोक्तुं भैक्ष्यमपीह लोके। हत्वार्थकामांस्तु गुरूनिहैव भुञ्जीय भोगान् रुधिरप्रदिग्धान्॥
translation: It would be better to live as a beggar in this world than to slay these noble elders. If I kill them, I will only enjoy wealth and desires tainted with their blood.

shloka: न चैतद्विद्मः कतरन्नो गरीयो यद्वा जयेम यदि वा नो जयेयुः। यानेव हत्वा न जिजीविषामस्तेऽवस्थिताः प्रमुखे धार्तराष्ट्राः॥
translation: I do not know what is better—to conquer them or to be conquered by them. Even if I survive, I will have no desire to live after killing Dhritarashtra’s sons who stand before me.

shloka: कार्पण्यदोषोपहतस्वभावः पृच्छामि त्वां धर्मसम्मूढचेताः। यच्छ्रेयः स्यान्निश्चितं ब्रूहि तन्मे शिष्यस्तेऽहं शाधि मां त्वां प्रपन्नम्॥
translation: My heart is overcome with weakness, and my mind is confused about duty. I ask You: Tell me decisively what is good for me. I am Your disciple. Please instruct me, for I have taken refuge in You.

shloka: न हि प्रपश्यामि ममापनुद्याद् यच्छोकमुच्छोषणमिन्द्रियाणाम्। अवाप्य भूमावसपत्नमृद्धं राज्यं सुराणामपि चाधिपत्यम्॥
translation: I see no way to dispel this grief that withers my senses. Even if I win unrivaled kingship on earth or the lordship of the gods, it will not avail me.

shloka: संजय उवाच। एवमुक्त्वा हृषीकेशं गुडाकेशः परंतपः। न योत्स्य इति गोविन्दमुक्त्वा तूष्णीं बभूव ह॥
translation: Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus to Krishna, Arjuna declared, 'I will not fight,' and fell silent.

shloka: तमुवाच हृषीकेशः प्रहसन्निव भारत। सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये विषीदन्तमिदं वचः॥
translation: O descendant of Bharata, Krishna smiled and spoke these words to the grief-stricken Arjuna between the two armies.

shloka: श्रीभगवानुवाच। अशोच्यानन्वशोचस्त्वं प्रज्ञावादांश्च भाषसे। गतासूनगतासूंश्च नानुशोचन्ति पण्डिताः॥
translation: The Lord said: You grieve for those who should not be grieved for, yet you speak words of wisdom. The wise lament neither for the living nor for the dead.

shloka: न त्वेवाहं जातु नासं न त्वं नेमे जनाधिपाः। न चैव न भविष्यामः सर्वे वयमतः परम्॥
translation: Never was there a time when I did not exist, nor you, nor these kings; nor will any of us cease to be hereafter.

shloka: देहिनोऽस्मिन्यथा देहे कौमारं यौवनं जरा। तथा देहान्तरप्राप्तिर्धीरस्तत्र न मुह्यति॥
translation: Just as the soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, it similarly passes into another body at death. The wise are not deluded by this.

shloka: मात्रास्पर्शास्तु कौन्तेय शीतोष्णसुखदुःखदाः। आगमापायिनोऽनित्यास्तांस्तितिक्षस्व भारत॥
translation: O Arjuna, the contact of the senses with their objects gives rise to fleeting perceptions of heat and cold, pleasure and pain. They come and go; endure them bravely.

shloka: यं हि न व्यथयन्त्येते पुरुषं पुरुषर्षभ। समदुःखसुखं धीरं सोऽमृतत्वाय कल्पते॥
translation: O best of men, the one who remains steady amid pleasure and pain, unshaken by these—such a person is fit for immortality.

shloka: नासतो विद्यते भावो नाभावो विद्यते सतः। उभयोरपि दृष्टोऽन्तस्त्वनयोस्तत्त्वदर्शिभिः॥
translation: The unreal has no existence, and the real never ceases to be. The wise perceive this truth about both.

shloka: अविनाशि तु तद्विद्धि येन सर्वमिदं ततम्। विनाशमव्ययस्यास्य न कश्चित्कर्तुमर्हति॥
translation: Know that which pervades this entire universe to be indestructible. No one can bring about the destruction of the imperishable.

shloka: अन्तवन्त इमे देहा नित्यस्योक्ताः शरीरिणः। अनाशिनोऽप्रमेयस्य तस्माद्युध्यस्व भारत॥
translation: These bodies are perishable, but the soul within is eternal, indestructible, and immeasurable. Therefore, fight, O Arjuna!

shloka: य एनं वेत्ति हन्तारं यश्चैनं मन्यते हतम्। उभौ तौ न विजानीतो नायं हन्ति न हन्यते॥
translation: One who thinks the soul can kill, and one who thinks it can be killed—both are mistaken. The soul neither kills nor is killed.

shloka: न जायते म्रियते वा कदाचिन्नायं भूत्वा भविता वा न भूयः। अजो नित्यः शाश्वतोऽयं पुराणो न हन्यते हन्यमाने शरीरे॥
translation: The soul is never born nor dies; it has no beginning or end. Unborn, eternal, and ancient, it is not slain when the body is slain.

shloka: वेदाविनाशिनं नित्यं य एनमजमव्ययम्। कथं स पुरुषः पार्थ कं घातयति हन्ति कम्॥
translation: O Arjuna, how can one who knows the soul to be imperishable, eternal, and unborn cause anyone to be killed or kill?

shloka: वासांसि जीर्णानि यथा विहाय नवानि गृह्णाति नरोऽपराणि। तथा शरीराणि विहाय जीर्णान्यन्यानि संयाति नवानि देही॥
translation: Just as a person discards worn-out clothes and puts on new ones, the soul discards old bodies and enters new ones.

shloka: नैनं छिन्दन्ति शस्त्राणि नैनं दहति पावकः। न चैनं क्लेदयन्त्यापो न शोषयति मारुतः॥
translation: Weapons cannot cut the soul, fire cannot burn it, water cannot wet it, and wind cannot dry it.

shloka: अच्छेद्योऽयमदाह्योऽयमक्लेद्योऽशोष्य एव च। नित्यः सर्वगतः स्थाणुरचलोऽयं सनातनः॥
translation: The soul is unbreakable, incombustible, insoluble, and unwithering. It is eternal, all-pervading, unchangeable, and immovable.

shloka: अव्यक्तोऽयमचिन्त्योऽयमविकार्योऽयमुच्यते। तस्मादेवं विदित्वैनं नानुशोचितुमर्हसि॥
translation: The soul is invisible, inconceivable, and immutable. Knowing this, you should not grieve.

shloka: अथ चैनं नित्यजातं नित्यं वा मन्यसे मृतम्। तथापि त्वं महाबाहो नैनं शोचितुमर्हसि॥
translation: Even if you think the soul is perpetually born or dies, O mighty-armed Arjuna, you still have no reason to lament.

shloka: जातस्य हि ध्रुवो मृत्युर्ध्रुवं जन्म मृतस्य च। तस्मादपरिहार्येऽर्थे न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि॥
translation: Death is certain for the born, and rebirth is certain for the dead. Since this is inevitable, you should not grieve.

shloka: अव्यक्तादीनि भूतानि व्यक्तमध्यानि भारत। अव्यक्तनिधनान्येव तत्र का परिदेवना॥
translation: All beings are unmanifest before birth, manifest in life, and unmanifest again after death. Why then lament?

shloka: आश्चर्यवत्पश्यति कश्चिदेनमाश्चर्यवद्वदति तथैव चान्यः। आश्चर्यवच्चैनमन्यः शृणोति श्रुत्वाप्येनं वेद न चैव कश्चित्॥
translation: Some see the soul as wondrous, others describe it as wondrous, and still others hear of it as wondrous—yet none truly know it.

shloka: देही नित्यमवध्योऽयं देहे सर्वस्य भारत। तस्मात्सर्वाणि भूतानि न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि॥
translation: O Arjuna, the soul within every being is eternal and cannot be slain. Therefore, you should not mourn for anyone.

shloka: स्वधर्ममपि चावेक्ष्य न विकम्पितुमर्हसि। धर्म्याद्धि युद्धाच्छ्रेयोऽन्यत्क्षत्रियस्य न विद्यते॥
translation: Considering your duty as a warrior, you must not waver. For a warrior, there is no greater good than a righteous war.

shloka: यदृच्छया चोपपन्नं स्वर्गद्वारमपावृतम्। सुखिनः क्षत्रियाः पार्थ लभन्ते युद्धमीदृशम्॥
translation: Happy are the warriors, O Arjuna, who find such a battle awaiting them—an open gate to heaven.

shloka: अथ चेत्त्वमिमं धर्म्यं संग्रामं न करिष्यसि। ततः स्वधर्मं कीर्तिं च हित्वा पापमवाप्स्यसि॥
translation: But if you refuse this righteous battle, you will abandon your duty and honor, incurring sin.

shloka: अकीर्तिं चापि भूतानि कथयिष्यन्ति तेऽव्ययाम्। सम्भावितस्य चाकीर्तिर्मरणादतिरिच्यते॥
translation: People will speak of your disgrace forever. For one honored as you are, infamy is worse than death.

shloka: भयाद्रणादुपरतं मंस्यन्ते त्वां महारथाः। येषां च त्वं बहुमतो भूत्वा यास्यसि लाघवम्॥
translation: The great warriors will think you withdrew from battle out of fear, and you will lose their respect.

shloka: अवाच्यवादांश्च बहून्वदिष्यन्ति तवाहिताः। निन्दन्तस्तव सामर्थ्यं ततो दुःखतरं नु किम्॥
translation: Your enemies will slander you with cruel words, mocking your strength. Could anything be more painful?

shloka: हतो वा प्राप्स्यसि स्वर्गं जित्वा वा भोक्ष्यसे महीम्। तस्मादुत्तिष्ठ कौन्तेय युद्धाय कृतनिश्चयः॥
translation: If slain, you will attain heaven; if victorious, you will enjoy the earth. Rise, O Arjuna, and fight with resolve!

shloka: सुखदुःखे समे कृत्वा लाभालाभौ जयाजयौ। ततो युद्धाय युज्यस्व नैवं पापमवाप्स्यसि॥
translation: Treat pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat alike. Engage in battle, and thus you will incur no sin.

shloka: एषा तेऽभिहिता साङ्ख्ये बुद्धिर्योगे त्विमां शृणु। बुद्ध्या युक्तो यया पार्थ कर्मबन्धं प्रहास्यसि॥
translation: Thus far, I have explained wisdom (Sankhya). Now listen to the path of action (Yoga), by which you will break free from bondage.

shloka: नेहाभिक्रमनाशोऽस्ति प्रत्यवायो न विद्यते। स्वल्पमप्यस्य धर्मस्य त्रायते महतो भयात्॥
translation: In this endeavor, no effort is wasted, and no adverse result exists. Even a little practice of this dharma protects one from great fear.

shloka: व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिरेकेह कुरुनन्दन। बहुशाखा ह्यनन्ताश्च बुद्धयोऽव्यवसायिनाम्॥
translation: O Arjuna, those resolved on this path have single-pointed determination. The irresolute have endless divisions of thought.

shloka: यामिमां पुष्पितां वाचं प्रवदन्त्यविपश्चितः। वेदवादरताः पार्थ नान्यदस्तीति वादिनः॥
translation: The ignorant delight in flowery Vedic words, claiming, 'There is nothing else,' obsessed with rituals for earthly rewards.

shloka: कामात्मानः स्वर्गपरा जन्मकर्मफलप्रदाम्। क्रियाविशेषबहुलां भोगैश्वर्यगतिं प्रति॥
translation: Desire-ridden, they fixate on heaven, performing elaborate rituals to secure power and pleasure in future births.

shloka: भोगैश्वर्यप्रसक्तानां तयापहृतचेतसाम्। व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिः समाधौ न विधीयते॥
translation: Minds clouded by attachment to pleasure and power cannot attain the steadiness of meditation.

shloka: त्रैगुण्यविषया वेदा निस्त्रैगुण्यो भवार्जुन। निर्द्वन्द्वो नित्यसत्त्वस्थो निर्योगक्षेम आत्मवान्॥
translation: The Vedas deal with the three modes of material nature. Rise above these, O Arjuna! Be free from duality, ever steadfast in purity, and unconcerned with acquisition.

shloka: यावानर्थ उदपाने सर्वतः संप्लुतोदके। तावान्सर्वेषु वेदेषु ब्राह्मणस्य विजानतः॥
translation: To the enlightened, all the Vedas are as useful as a small pond when a great flood covers the land.

shloka: कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन। मा कर्मफलहेतुर्भूर्मा ते सङ्गोऽस्त्वकर्मणि॥
translation: You have the right to perform your duties, but never to the fruits of your actions. Never act for reward, yet never cease to act.

shloka: योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा धनञ्जय। सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योः समो भूत्वा समत्वं योग उच्यते॥
translation: Perform your duty equipoised, O Arjuna, abandoning attachment to success or failure. Such evenness of mind is called Yoga.

shloka: दूरेण ह्यवरं कर्म बुद्धियोगाद्धनञ्जय। बुद्धौ शरणमन्विच्छ कृपणाः फलहेतवः॥
translation: Far inferior is mere action to the wisdom of discernment, O Arjuna. Seek refuge in wisdom—pitiful are those motivated by results.

shloka: बुद्धियुक्तो जहातीह उभे सुकृतदुष्कृते। तस्माद्योगाय युज्यस्व योगः कर्मसु कौशलम्॥
translation: The wise rise above good and bad deeds in this life. Therefore, devote yourself to Yoga, for skill in action lies in Yoga.

shloka: कर्मजं बुद्धियुक्ता हि फलं त्यक्त्वा मनीषिणः। जन्मबन्धविनिर्मुक्ताः पदं गच्छन्त्यनामयम्॥
translation: The wise, free from attachment to results, are liberated from the cycle of birth and attain the state beyond sorrow.

shloka: यदा ते मोहकलिलं बुद्धिर्व्यतितरिष्यति। तदा गन्तासि निर्वेदं श्रोतव्यस्य श्रुतस्य च॥
translation: When your intellect pierces the veil of delusion, you will become indifferent to all you have heard or may hear.

shloka: श्रुतिविप्रतिपन्ना ते यदा स्थास्यति निश्चला। समाधावचला बुद्धिस्तदा योगमवाप्स्यसि॥
translation: When your mind, unmoved by conflicting scriptures, remains steady in meditation, you will attain Yoga.

shloka: अर्जुन उवाच। स्थितप्रज्ञस्य का भाषा समाधिस्थस्य केशव। स्थितधीः किं प्रभाषेत किमासीत व्रजेत किम्॥
translation: Arjuna said: O Krishna, how does one of steady wisdom speak? How does he sit, walk, or act?

shloka: श्रीभगवानुवाच। प्रजहाति यदा कामान्सर्वान्पार्थ मनोगतान्। आत्मन्येवात्मना तुष्टः स्थितप्रज्ञस्तदोच्यते॥
translation: The Lord said: O Arjuna, when one renounces all selfish desires and finds contentment in the Self alone, that is the state of steady wisdom.

shloka: दुःखेष्वनुद्विग्नमनाः सुखेषु विगतस्पृहः। वीतरागभयक्रोधः स्थितधीर्मुनिरुच्यते॥
translation: One whose mind remains undisturbed in sorrow, who is free from craving in pleasure, and who has transcended attachment, fear, and anger—such a sage is called steadfast.

shloka: यः सर्वत्रानभिस्नेहस्तत्तत्प्राप्य शुभाशुभम्। नाभिनन्दति न द्वेष्टि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता॥
translation: One who is unattached to anything, who neither rejoices nor despises whatever comes—his wisdom is firmly established.

shloka: यदा संहरते चायं कूर्मोऽङ्गानीव सर्वशः। इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता॥
translation: When one withdraws the senses from their objects, like a tortoise retracting its limbs, wisdom becomes steady.

shloka: विषया विनिवर्तन्ते निराहारस्य देहिनः। रसवर्जं रसोऽप्यस्य परं दृष्ट्वा निवर्तते॥
translation: Even abstaining from sense objects, the craving for them remains. But for one who has glimpsed the Supreme, even this craving ceases.

shloka: यततो ह्यपि कौन्तेय पुरुषस्य विपश्चितः। इन्द्रियाणि प्रमाथीनि हरन्ति प्रसभं मनः॥
translation: O Arjuna, even the wise struggle against restless senses that violently carry away the mind.

shloka: तानि सर्वाणि संयम्य युक्त आसीत मत्परः। वशे हि यस्येन्द्रियाणि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता॥
translation: One who restrains the senses and fixes the mind on Me is a person of steady wisdom.

shloka: ध्यायतो विषयान्पुंसः सङ्गस्तेषूपजायते। सङ्गात्संजायते कामः कामात्क्रोधोऽभिजायते॥
translation: Brooding on sense objects breeds attachment; attachment breeds desire; and unfulfilled desire breeds anger.

shloka: क्रोधाद्भवति सम्मोहः सम्मोहात्स्मृतिविभ्रमः। स्मृतिभ्रंशाद् बुद्धिनाशो बुद्धिनाशात्प्रणश्यति॥
translation: Anger leads to delusion; delusion clouds memory; memory lost destroys wisdom; and without wisdom, one perishes.

shloka: रागद्वेषवियुक्तैस्तु विषयानिन्द्रियैश्चरन्। आत्मवश्यैर्विधेयात्मा प्रसादमधिगच्छति॥
translation: But one who masters the senses, free from attraction and aversion, attains peace.

shloka: प्रसादे सर्वदुःखानां हानिरस्योपजायते। प्रसन्नचेतसो ह्याशु बुद्धिः पर्यवतिष्ठते॥
translation: In peace, all sorrows dissolve, and the intellect of the serene quickly becomes steady.

shloka: नास्ति बुद्धिरयुक्तस्य न चायुक्तस्य भावना। न चाभावयतः शान्तिरशान्तस्य कुतः सुखम्॥
translation: The undisciplined have no wisdom, no meditation; without meditation, there is no peace. How can there be happiness without peace?

shloka: इन्द्रियाणां हि चरतां यन्मनोऽनुविधीयते। तदस्य हरति प्रज्ञां वायुर्नावमिवाम्भसि॥
translation: For the mind that yields to the wandering senses carries away wisdom, as the wind carries a ship off course.

shloka: तस्माद्यस्य महाबाहो निगृहीतानि सर्वशः। इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता॥
translation: Therefore, O mighty-armed Arjuna, one who completely restrains the senses from their objects—their wisdom stands firm.

shloka: या निशा सर्वभूतानां तस्यां जागर्ति संयमी। यस्यां जाग्रति भूतानि सा निशा पश्यतो मुनेः॥
translation: What is night for all beings is the time of awakening for the self-controlled. And when others are awake, the sage perceives it as night.

shloka: आपूर्यमाणमचलप्रतिष्ठं समुद्रमापः प्रविशन्ति यद्वत्। तद्वत्कामा यं प्रविशन्ति सर्वे स शान्तिमाप्नोति न कामकामी॥
translation: Just as the ocean remains undisturbed by the flow of rivers, so the wise remain unmoved by desires. Only such attain peace—not those who crave desires.

shloka: विहाय कामान्यः सर्वान्पुमांश्चरति निःस्पृहः। निर्ममो निरहंकारः स शान्तिमधिगच्छति॥
translation: One who abandons all desires, free from longing and ego, attains perfect peace.

shloka: एषा ब्राह्मी स्थितिः पार्थ नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति। स्थित्वास्यामन्तकालेऽपि ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृच्छति॥
translation: This is the state of divine union, O Arjuna. Attaining it, one is no longer deluded. Established in it even at death, one merges with the Absolute.

shloka: अर्जुन उवाच। ज्यायसी चेत्कर्मणस्ते मता बुद्धिर्जनार्दन। तत्किं कर्मणि घोरे मां नियोजयसि केशव॥
translation: Arjuna said: O Janardana, if You consider wisdom superior to action, why then do You urge me to engage in this terrible war?

shloka: व्यामिश्रेणेव वाक्येन बुद्धिं मोहयसीव मे। तदेकं वद निश्चित्य येन श्रेयोऽहमाप्नुयाम्॥
translation: Your words confuse me. Tell me decisively: Which path should I follow to attain the highest good?

shloka: श्रीभगवानुवाच। लोकेऽस्मिन्द्विविधा निष्ठा पुरा प्रोक्ता मयानघ। ज्ञानयोगेन साङ्ख्यानां कर्मयोगेन योगिनाम्॥
translation: The Lord said: O sinless one, I have taught two paths in this world: the path of knowledge for the contemplative and the path of action for the active.

shloka: न कर्मणामनारम्भान्नैष्कर्म्यं पुरुषोऽश्नुते। न च संन्यसनादेव सिद्धिं समधिगच्छति॥
translation: One cannot attain freedom from actions by merely avoiding work, nor can one achieve perfection by mere renunciation.

shloka: न हि कश्चित्क्षणमपि जातु तिष्ठत्यकर्मकृत्। कार्यते ह्यवशः कर्म सर्वः प्रकृतिजैर्गुणैः॥
translation: No one can remain inactive even for a moment. Everyone is forced to act by the qualities born of material nature.

shloka: कर्मेन्द्रियाणि संयम्य य आस्ते मनसा स्मरन्। इन्द्रियार्थान्विमूढात्मा मिथ्याचारः स उच्यते॥
translation: One who restrains the senses but dwells mentally on sense objects is a hypocrite and deludes oneself.

shloka: यस्त्विन्द्रियाणि मनसा नियम्यारभतेऽर्जुन। कर्मेन्द्रियैः कर्मयोगमसक्तः स विशिष्यते॥
translation: But O Arjuna, one who controls the senses with the mind and engages in selfless action with the organs of action—such a person excels.

shloka: नियतं कुरु कर्म त्वं कर्म ज्यायो ह्यकर्मणः। शरीरयात्रापि च ते न प्रसिद्ध्येदकर्मणः॥
translation: Perform your prescribed duties, for action is better than inaction. Even maintaining your body would be impossible without action.

shloka: यज्ञार्थात्कर्मणोऽन्यत्र लोकोऽयं कर्मबन्धनः। तदर्थं कर्म कौन्तेय मुक्तसङ्गः समाचर॥
translation: O Arjuna, actions bind the world unless done as a sacrifice. Therefore, perform duty for sacrifice alone, free from attachment.

shloka: सहयज्ञाः प्रजाः सृष्ट्वा पुरोवाच प्रजापतिः। अनेन प्रसविष्यध्वमेष वोऽस्त्विष्टकामधुक्॥
translation: In ancient times, the Creator created humans along with sacrifices and said: ‘By this, may you prosper. Let it fulfill your desires.’

shloka: देवान्भावयतानेन ते देवा भावयन्तु वः। परस्परं भावयन्तः श्रेयः परमवाप्स्यथ॥
translation: Nourish the gods with sacrifices, and they will nourish you. Thus, supporting one another, you shall attain the highest good.

shloka: इष्टान्भोगान्हि वो देवा दास्यन्ते यज्ञभाविताः। तैर्दत्तानप्रदायैभ्यो यो भुङ्क्ते स्तेन एव सः॥
translation: The gods, pleased by sacrifices, will grant you prosperity. But one who enjoys their gifts without offering in return is a thief.

shloka: यज्ञशिष्टाशिनः सन्तो मुच्यन्ते सर्वकिल्बिषैः। भुञ्जते ते त्वघं पापा ये पचन्त्यात्मकारणात्॥
translation: The virtuous who eat the remnants of sacrifice are freed from sin. But the wicked who cook only for themselves feed on sin.

shloka: अन्नाद्भवन्ति भूतानि पर्जन्यादन्नसंभवः। यज्ञाद्भवति पर्जन्यो यज्ञः कर्मसमुद्भवः॥
translation: All beings arise from food, food from rain, rain from sacrifice, and sacrifice from selfless action.

shloka: कर्म ब्रह्मोद्भवं विद्धि ब्रह्माक्षरसमुद्भवम्। तस्मात्सर्वगतं ब्रह्म नित्यं यज्ञे प्रतिष्ठितम्॥
translation: Know that action originates from the Vedas, and the Vedas arise from the Eternal. Thus, the all-pervading Brahman is eternally rooted in sacrifice.

shloka: एवं प्रवर्तितं चक्रं नानुवर्तयतीह यः। अघायुरिन्द्रियारामो मोघं पार्थ स जीवति॥
translation: O Arjuna, one who does not follow this cycle of sacrifice lives in vain, indulging the senses and harming the self.

shloka: यस्त्वात्मरतिरेव स्यादात्मतृप्तश्च मानवः। आत्मन्येव च सन्तुष्टस्तस्य कार्यं न विद्यते॥
translation: But one who rejoices in the Self, is satisfied in the Self, and finds contentment in the Self alone—for such a person, there is no duty.

shloka: नैव तस्य कृतेनार्थो नाकृतेनेह कश्चन। न चास्य सर्वभूतेषु कश्चिदर्थव्यपाश्रयः॥
translation: For such a person, there is no need to act or refrain from action. Nor do they depend on any being for any purpose.

shloka: तस्मादसक्तः सततं कार्यं कर्म समाचर। असक्तो ह्याचरन्कर्म परमाप्नोति पूरुषः॥
translation: Therefore, always perform your duty without attachment. By working selflessly, one attains the Supreme.

shloka: कर्मणैव हि संसिद्धिमास्थिता जनकादयः। लोकसंग्रहमेवापि संपश्यन्कर्तुमर्हसि॥
translation: Even kings like Janaka attained perfection through selfless action. For the welfare of the world, you too should act.

shloka: यद्यदाचरति श्रेष्ठस्तत्तदेवेतरो जनः। स यत्प्रमाणं कुरुते लोकस्तदनुवर्तते॥
translation: Whatever actions great beings perform, common people follow. Whatever standards they set, the world emulates.

shloka: न मे पार्थास्ति कर्तव्यं त्रिषु लोकेषु किञ्चन। नानवाप्तमवाप्तव्यं वर्त एव च कर्मणि॥
translation: O Arjuna, I have no duty left to fulfill in all the worlds, nor is there anything I lack—yet I continue to act.

shloka: यदि ह्यहं न वर्तेयं जातु कर्मण्यतन्द्रितः। मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः॥
translation: For if I ever ceased to act diligently, people everywhere would follow My example and abandon their duties.

shloka: उत्सीदेयुरिमे लोका न कुर्यां कर्म चेदहम्। संकरस्य च कर्ता स्यामुपहन्यामिमाः प्रजाः॥
translation: If I stopped acting, these worlds would perish. I would be the cause of chaos and the destruction of humanity.

shloka: सक्ताः कर्मण्यविद्वांसो यथा कुर्वन्ति भारत। कुर्याद्विद्वांस्तथासक्तश्चिकीर्षुर्लोकसंग्रहम्॥
translation: As the ignorant act with attachment, O Arjuna, so should the wise act—but without attachment—for the welfare of the world.

shloka: न बुद्धिभेदं जनयेदज्ञानां कर्मसङ्गिनाम्। जोषयेत्सर्वकर्माणि विद्वान्युक्तः समाचरन्॥
translation: Let the wise not unsettle the minds of the ignorant who are attached to action. Instead, they should inspire others to perform all duties with devotion.

shloka: प्रकृतेः क्रियमाणानि गुणैः कर्माणि सर्वशः। अहंकारविमूढात्मा कर्ताहमिति मन्यते॥
translation: All actions are performed by the modes of material nature, but the deluded, blinded by ego, think, ‘I am the doer.’

shloka: तत्त्ववित्तु महाबाहो गुणकर्मविभागयोः। गुणा गुणेषु वर्तन्त इति मत्वा न सज्जते॥
translation: O mighty-armed Arjuna, one who understands the truth about the divisions of the modes of nature and their actions knows that the modes interact with the modes alone, and thus remains unattached.

shloka: प्रकृतेर्गुणसम्मूढाः सज्जन्ते गुणकर्मसु। तानकृत्स्नविदो मन्दान्कृत्स्नविन्न विचालयेत्॥
translation: Those deluded by the modes of nature become attached to their actions. But the wise should not disturb the ignorant, who lack complete knowledge.

shloka: मयि सर्वाणि कर्माणि संन्यस्याध्यात्मचेतसा। निराशीर्निर्ममो भूत्वा युध्यस्व विगतज्वरः॥
translation: Surrender all your actions to Me, with your mind fixed on the Self. Free from desire and ego, fight! Let go of your feverish anxiety.

shloka: ये मे मतमिदं नित्यमनुतिष्ठन्ति मानवाः। श्रद्धावन्तोऽनसूयन्तो मुच्यन्ते तेऽपि कर्मभिः॥
translation: Those who always follow this teaching of Mine with faith and without envy are freed from the bondage of actions.

shloka: ये त्वेतदभ्यसूयन्तो नानुतिष्ठन्ति मे मतम्। सर्वज्ञानविमूढांस्तान्विद्धि नष्टानचेतसः॥
translation: But those who criticize this teaching and do not follow it—know them to be fools, lost in ignorance and doomed.

shloka: सदृशं चेष्टते स्वस्याः प्रकृतेर्ज्ञानवानपि। प्रकृतिं यान्ति भूतानि निग्रहः किं करिष्यति॥
translation: Even the wise act according to their nature. All beings follow their inherent tendencies. What can repression achieve?

shloka: इन्द्रियस्येन्द्रियस्यार्थे रागद्वेषौ व्यवस्थितौ। तयोर्न वशमागच्छेत्तौ ह्यस्य परिपन्थिनौ॥
translation: Attachment and aversion for sense objects are fixed in the senses. Do not fall under their sway, for they are your enemies.

shloka: श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात्। स्वधर्मे निधनं श्रेयः परधर्मो भयावहः॥
translation: It is better to perform one’s own duty imperfectly than another’s duty perfectly. Better to die in one’s own duty; another’s duty is fraught with danger.

shloka: अर्जुन उवाच। अथ केन प्रयुक्तोऽयं पापं चरति पूरुषः। अनिच्छन्नपि वार्ष्णेय बलादिव नियोजितः॥
translation: Arjuna said: O Krishna, what drives a person to sin, even against their own will, as if compelled by force?

shloka: श्रीभगवानुवाच। काम एष क्रोध एष रजोगुणसमुद्भवः। महाशनो महापाप्मा विद्ध्येनमिह वैरिणम्॥
translation: The Lord said: It is desire—born of the mode of passion—then anger, the all-devouring, sinful enemy of this world.

shloka: धूमेनाव्रियते वह्निर्यथादर्शो मलेन च। यथोल्बेनावृतो गर्भस्तथा तेनेदमावृतम्॥
translation: As fire is obscured by smoke, a mirror by dust, and a fetus by the womb, so wisdom is veiled by desire.

shloka: आवृतं ज्ञानमेतेन ज्ञानिनो नित्यवैरिणा। कामरूपेण कौन्तेय दुष्पूरेणानलेन च॥
translation: O Arjuna, wisdom is covered by this eternal foe of the wise—desire, an insatiable fire.

shloka: इन्द्रियाणि मनो बुद्धिरस्याधिष्ठानमुच्यते। एतैर्विमोहयत्येष ज्ञानमावृत्य देहिनम्॥
translation: The senses, mind, and intellect are said to be desire’s strongholds. Through them, it deludes the soul by veiling wisdom.

shloka: तस्मात्त्वमिन्द्रियाण्यादौ नियम्य भरतर्षभ। पाप्मानं प्रजहि ह्येनं ज्ञानविज्ञाननाशनम्॥
translation: Therefore, O Arjuna, first control the senses, and slay this enemy—desire, the destroyer of knowledge and realization.

shloka: इन्द्रियाणि पराण्याहुरिन्द्रियेभ्यः परं मनः। मनसस्तु परा बुद्धिर्यो बुद्धेः परतस्तु सः॥
translation: The senses are superior to the body, the mind is superior to the senses, the intellect is superior to the mind, and the soul is superior to the intellect.

shloka: एवं बुद्धेः परं बुद्ध्वा संस्तभ्यात्मानमात्मना। जहि शत्रुं महाबाहो कामरूपं दुरासदम्॥
translation: O mighty-armed Arjuna, knowing the soul to be beyond the intellect, steady the mind with spiritual discipline and conquer this insatiable enemy—desire.

shloka: श्रीभगवानुवाच। इमं विवस्वते योगं प्रोक्तवानहमव्ययम्। विवस्वान्मनवे प्राह मनुरिक्ष्वाकवेऽब्रवीत्॥
translation: The Lord said: I taught this eternal Yoga to Vivasvan (the sun-god), who taught it to Manu, who then taught it to Ikshvaku.

shloka: एवं परम्पराप्राप्तमिमं राजर्षयो विदुः। स कालेनेह महता योगो नष्टः परन्तप॥
translation: O subduer of foes, this supreme knowledge was passed down through this chain of disciples, but over time, it was lost to the world.

shloka: स एवायं मया तेऽद्य योगः प्रोक्तः पुरातनः। भक्तोऽसि मे सखा चेति रहस्यं ह्येतदुत्तमम्॥
translation: Today, I am revealing this same ancient Yoga to you, for you are My devotee and friend. This is the supreme secret.

shloka: अर्जुन उवाच। अपरं भवतो जन्म परं जन्म विवस्वतः। कथमेतद्विजानीयां त्वमादौ प्रोक्तवानिति॥
translation: Arjuna said: You were born later, but Vivasvan lived long ago. How am I to understand that You taught this yoga in the beginning?

shloka: श्रीभगवानुवाच। बहूनि मे व्यतीतानि जन्मानि तव चार्जुन। तान्यहं वेद सर्वाणि न त्वं वेत्थ परन्तप॥
translation: The Lord said: Both you and I have passed through many births, O Arjuna. I remember them all, but you do not.

shloka: अजोऽपि सन्नव्ययात्मा भूतानामीश्वरोऽपि सन्। प्रकृतिं स्वामधिष्ठाय संभवाम्यात्ममायया॥
translation: Though I am unborn and My soul is eternal, though I am the Lord of all beings, I manifest through My own divine power by taking birth in My own nature.

shloka: यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत। अभ्युत्थानमधर्मस्य तदात्मानं सृजाम्यहम्॥
translation: Whenever righteousness declines and unrighteousness rises, O Arjuna, I manifest Myself in this world.

shloka: परित्राणाय साधूनां विनाशाय च दुष्कृताम्। धर्मसंस्थापनार्थाय सम्भवामि युगे युगे॥
translation: To protect the righteous, to destroy the wicked, and to reestablish dharma, I appear age after age.

shloka: जन्म कर्म च मे दिव्यमेवं यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः। त्यक्त्वा देहं पुनर्जन्म नैति मामेति सोऽर्जुन॥
translation: One who truly understands My divine birth and actions, O Arjuna, is not reborn after death but attains Me.

shloka: वीतरागभयक्रोधा मन्मया मामुपाश्रिताः। बहवो ज्ञानतपसा पूता मद्भावमागताः॥
translation: Freed from attachment, fear, and anger, absorbed in Me and taking refuge in Me, many have attained My divine state through the fire of knowledge.

shloka: ये यथा मां प्रपद्यन्ते तांस्तथैव भजाम्यहम्। मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः॥
translation: As people approach Me, so I receive them. All paths, O Arjuna, lead to Me.

shloka: काङ्क्षन्तः कर्मणां सिद्धिं यजन्त इह देवताः। क्षिप्रं हि मानुषे लोके सिद्धिर्भवति कर्मजा॥
translation: Those who desire success in their actions worship the gods here, for in this human world, success comes quickly from such rites.

shloka: चातुर्वर्ण्यं मया सृष्टं गुणकर्मविभागशः। तस्य कर्तारमपि मां विद्ध्यकर्तारमव्ययम्॥
translation: I created the four varnas based on qualities and duties. Though I am the creator, know Me to be the eternal non-doer.

shloka: न मां कर्माणि लिम्पन्ति न मे कर्मफले स्पृहा। इति मां योऽभिजानाति कर्मभिर्न स बध्यते॥
translation: Actions do not taint Me, nor do I crave their results. One who understands this truth is not bound by actions.

shloka: एवं ज्ञात्वा कृतं कर्म पूर्वैरपि मुमुक्षुभिः। कुरु कर्मैव तस्मात्त्वं पूर्वैः पूर्वतरं कृतम्॥
translation: Knowing this, even the ancient seekers performed their duties. Therefore, do your duty as they did.

shloka: किं कर्म किमकर्मेति कवयोऽप्यत्र मोहिताः। तत्ते कर्म प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात्॥
translation: What is action? What is inaction? Even the wise are confused about this. I will explain it to you so that you may be free from misfortune.

shloka: कर्मणो ह्यपि बोद्धव्यं बोद्धव्यं च विकर्मणः। अकर्मणश्च बोद्धव्यं गहना कर्मणो गतिः॥
translation: You must understand the nature of right action, forbidden action, and inaction. The path of action is profound.

shloka: कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येदकर्मणि च कर्म यः। स बुद्धिमान्मनुष्येषु स युक्तः कृत्स्नकर्मकृत्॥
translation: One who sees inaction in action and action in inaction is wise among men. Such a person is a yogi who has accomplished all duties.

shloka: यस्य सर्वे समारम्भाः कामसङ्कल्पवर्जिताः। ज्ञानाग्निदग्धकर्माणं तमाहुः पण्डितं बुधाः॥
translation: One whose every act is free from selfish desire, whose actions are burned in the fire of knowledge—the wise call such a person learned.

shloka: त्यक्त्वा कर्मफलासङ्गं नित्यतृप्तो निराश्रयः। कर्मण्यभिप्रवृत्तोऽपि नैव किञ्चित्करोति सः॥
translation: Abandoning attachment to results, ever content and independent, one who acts—though engaged in action—does nothing at all.

shloka: निराशीर्यतचित्तात्मा त्यक्तसर्वपरिग्रहः। शारीरं केवलं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम्॥
translation: Free from expectations, with mind and self controlled, giving up all possessions, one who performs mere bodily action incurs no sin.

shloka: यदृच्छालाभसन्तुष्टो द्वन्द्वातीतो विमत्सरः। समः सिद्धावसिद्धौ च कृत्वापि न निबध्यते॥
translation: Content with whatever comes by chance, beyond duality, free from envy, equal in success and failure—such a person is not bound even when acting.

shloka: गतसङ्गस्य मुक्तस्य ज्ञानावस्थितचेतसः। यज्ञायाचरतः कर्म समग्रं प्रविलीयते॥
translation: For one who is free from attachment, liberated, with mind fixed in knowledge—all actions dissolve entirely when performed as a sacrifice.

shloka: ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविर्ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा हुतम्। ब्रह्मैव तेन गन्तव्यं ब्रह्मकर्मसमाधिना॥
translation: The offering is Brahman, the oblation is Brahman, poured by Brahman into the fire of Brahman. One who realizes Brahman in action attains Brahman alone.

shloka: दैवमेवापरे यज्ञं योगिनः पर्युपासते। ब्रह्माग्नावपरे यज्ञं यज्ञेनैवोपजुह्वति॥
translation: Some yogis worship the gods through sacrifice, while others offer sacrifice itself into the fire of Brahman.

shloka: श्रोत्रादीनीन्द्रियाण्यन्ये संयमाग्निषु जुह्वति। शब्दादीन्विषयानन्य इन्द्रियाग्निषु जुह्वति॥
translation: Some offer hearing and other senses into the fires of restraint, while others offer sound and other sense objects into the fires of the senses.

shloka: सर्वाणीन्द्रियकर्माणि प्राणकर्माणि चापरे। आत्मसंयमयोगाग्नौ जुह्वति ज्ञानदीपिते॥
translation: Others sacrifice all functions of the senses and the vital forces into the fire of self-control, kindled by knowledge.

shloka: द्रव्ययज्ञास्तपोयज्ञा योगयज्ञास्तथापरे। स्वाध्यायज्ञानयज्ञाश्च यतयः संशितव्रताः॥
translation: Some offer wealth as sacrifice, others offer austerity, while others practice yoga or study scriptures—all with strict vows.

shloka: अपाने जुह्वति प्राणं प्राणेऽपानं तथापरे। प्राणापानगती रुद्ध्वा प्राणायामपरायणाः॥
translation: Some restrain the flow of prana and apana (incoming and outgoing breath), while others offer prana into apana through breath control.

shloka: अपरे नियताहाराः प्राणान्प्राणेषु जुह्वति। सर्वेऽप्येते यज्ञविदो यज्ञक्षपितकल्मषाः॥
translation: Others regulate their diet and offer the life force into the life force. All these knowers of sacrifice purify themselves through sacrifice.

shloka: यज्ञशिष्टामृतभुजो यान्ति ब्रह्म सनातनम्। नायं लोकोऽस्त्ययज्ञस्य कुतोऽन्यः कुरुसत्तम॥
translation: Those who partake of the nectar of sacrifice attain the eternal Brahman. O best of the Kurus, even this world is not for the non-sacrificer—how then the next?

shloka: एवं बहुविधा यज्ञा वितता ब्रह्मणो मुखे। कर्मजान्विद्धि तान्सर्वानेवं ज्ञात्वा विमोक्ष्यसे॥
translation: Thus, many forms of sacrifice are spread before Brahman. Know them all to be born of action, and thus you shall be liberated.

shloka: श्रेयान्द्रव्यमयाद्यज्ञाज्ज्ञानयज्ञः परन्तप। सर्वं कर्माखिलं पार्थ ज्ञाने परिसमाप्यते॥
translation: O subduer of foes, the sacrifice of knowledge is superior to material sacrifices, for all actions culminate in wisdom.

shloka: तद्विद्धि प्रणिपातेन परिप्रश्नेन सेवया। उपदेक्ष्यन्ति ते ज्ञानं ज्ञानिनस्तत्त्वदर्शिनः॥
translation: Learn that knowledge by humble submission, by inquiry, and by service. The wise who see the truth will instruct you.

shloka: यज्ज्ञात्वा न पुनर्मोहमेवं यास्यसि पाण्डव। येन भूतान्यशेषेण द्रक्ष्यस्यात्मन्यथो मयि॥
translation: Knowing this, O Pandava, you will never again be deluded. Through this knowledge, you will see all beings in yourself and then in Me.

shloka: अपि चेदसि पापेभ्यः सर्वेभ्यः पापकृत्तमः। सर्वं ज्ञानप्लवेनैव वृजिनं सन्तरिष्यसि॥
translation: Even if you are the worst of sinners, you shall cross all sin by the raft of knowledge.

shloka: यथैधांसि समिद्धोऽग्निर्भस्मसात्कुरुतेऽर्जुन। ज्ञानाग्निः सर्वकर्माणि भस्मसात्कुरुते तथा॥
translation: As a blazing fire reduces wood to ashes, O Arjuna, so does the fire of knowledge burn all actions to ashes.

shloka: न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते। तत्स्वयं योगसंसिद्धः कालेनात्मनि विन्दति॥
translation: In this world, nothing purifies like knowledge. The perfected yogi finds this in due time within oneself.

shloka: श्रद्धावाँल्लभते ज्ञानं तत्परः संयतेन्द्रियः। ज्ञानं लब्ध्वा परां शान्तिमचिरेणाधिगच्छति॥
translation: The faithful, devoted, and self-controlled one attains knowledge. Having attained it, they soon find supreme peace.

shloka: अज्ञश्चाश्रद्दधानश्च संशयात्मा विनश्यति। नायं लोकोऽस्ति न परो न सुखं संशयात्मनः॥
translation: The ignorant, the faithless, and the doubting self perish. For the doubter, there is neither this world nor the next, nor happiness.

shloka: योगसंन्यस्तकर्माणं ज्ञानसंछिन्नसंशयम्। आत्मवन्तं न कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनञ्जय॥
translation: O Arjuna, actions do not bind one who has renounced them through yoga, whose doubts are destroyed by knowledge, and who is self-possessed.

shloka: तस्मादज्ञानसम्भूतं हृत्स्थं ज्ञानासिनात्मनः। छित्त्वैनं संशयं योगमातिष्ठोत्तिष्ठ भारत॥
translation: Therefore, with the sword of knowledge, cut through this doubt born of ignorance in your heart. Take refuge in yoga, O Arjuna, and arise!

shloka: अर्जुन उवाच। संन्यासं कर्मणां कृष्ण पुनर्योगं च शंससि। यच्छ्रेय एतयोरेकं तन्मे ब्रूहि सुनिश्चितम्॥
translation: Arjuna said: O Krishna, You praise both renunciation of actions and also selfless service. Tell me decisively which one is truly better.

shloka: श्रीभगवानुवाच। संन्यासः कर्मयोगश्च निःश्रेयसकरावुभौ। तयोस्तु कर्मसंन्यासात्कर्मयोगो विशिष्यते॥
translation: The Lord said: Both renunciation and selfless action lead to liberation. But of the two, selfless service is superior to mere renunciation.

shloka: ज्ञेयः स नित्यसंन्यासी यो न द्वेष्टि न काङ्क्षति। निर्द्वन्द्वो हि महाबाहो सुखं बन्धात्प्रमुच्यते॥
translation: Know that person to be a true renunciant who neither hates nor desires, O mighty-armed Arjuna. Free from duality, they are easily liberated from bondage.

shloka: साङ्ख्ययोगौ पृथग्बालाः प्रवदन्ति न पण्डिताः। एकमप्यास्थितः सम्यगुभयोर्विन्दते फलम्॥
translation: Only the ignorant say that Sankhya (knowledge) and Yoga (action) are different. The wise know that whoever pursues either path wholeheartedly attains the fruits of both.

shloka: यत्साङ्ख्यैः प्राप्यते स्थानं तद्योगैरपि गम्यते। एकं साङ्ख्यं च योगं च यः पश्यति स पश्यति॥
translation: The state attained by the path of knowledge is also reached by the path of action. One who sees knowledge and action as one truly sees.

shloka: संन्यासस्तु महाबाहो दुःखमाप्तुमयोगतः। योगयुक्तो मुनिर्ब्रह्म नचिरेणाधिगच्छति॥
translation: O mighty-armed Arjuna, renunciation without selfless action is painful to attain. But the sage united with Yoga swiftly attains Brahman.

shloka: योगयुक्तो विशुद्धात्मा विजितात्मा जितेन्द्रियः। सर्वभूतात्मभूतात्मा कुर्वन्नपि न लिप्यते॥
translation: One who is united with Yoga, pure in heart, self-controlled, and seeing all beings as oneself—though acting, they are never bound.

shloka: नैव किञ्चित्करोमीति युक्तो मन्येत तत्त्ववित्। पश्यञ्शृण्वन्स्पृशञ्जिघ्रन्नश्नन्गच्छन्स्वपञ्श्वसन्॥
translation: The knower of truth, united with Yoga, thinks: 'I do nothing at all'—even while seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, eating, moving, sleeping, or breathing.

shloka: प्रलपन्विसृजन्गृह्ण्न्नुन्मिषन्निमिषन्नपि। इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेषु वर्तन्त इति धारयन्॥
translation: Speaking, letting go, holding, opening and closing the eyes—one who understands that only the senses interact with sense objects remains unattached.

shloka: ब्रह्मण्याधाय कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा करोति यः। लिप्यते न स पापेन पद्मपत्रमिवाम्भसा॥
translation: One who dedicates all actions to Brahman, abandoning attachment, is no more tainted by sin than a lotus leaf is touched by water.

shloka: कायेन मनसा बुद्ध्या केवलैरिन्द्रियैरपि। योगिनः कर्म कुर्वन्ति सङ्गं त्यक्त्वात्मशुद्धये॥
translation: Yogis perform actions only with the body, mind, intellect, or senses, abandoning attachment, for the purification of the self.

shloka: युक्तः कर्मफलं त्यक्त्वा शान्तिमाप्नोति नैष्ठिकीम्। अयुक्तः कामकारेण फले सक्तो निबध्यते॥
translation: The united one, renouncing the fruits of action, attains abiding peace. The disunited, attached to results, becomes bound.

shloka: सर्वकर्माणि मनसा संन्यस्यास्ते सुखं वशी। नवद्वारे पुरे देही नैव कुर्वन्न कारयन्॥
translation: When the embodied soul mentally renounces all actions and rests happily in the city of nine gates (the body), neither acting nor causing action.

shloka: न कर्तृत्वं न कर्माणि लोकस्य सृजति प्रभुः। न कर्मफलसंयोगं स्वभावस्तु प्रवर्तते॥
translation: The Lord creates neither agency nor actions for the world, nor the fruits of actions. All this is enacted by the modes of nature.

shloka: नादत्ते कस्यचित्पापं न चैव सुकृतं विभुः। अज्ञानेनावृतं ज्ञानं तेन मुह्यन्ति जन्तवः॥
translation: The Supreme Lord does not take responsibility for anyone's sin or virtue. Wisdom is covered by ignorance, and thereby creatures are deluded.

shloka: ज्ञानेन तु तदज्ञानं येषां नाशितमात्मनः। तेषामादित्यवज्ज्ञानं प्रकाशयति तत्परम्॥
translation: But when ignorance is destroyed by wisdom, that knowledge reveals the Supreme, like the sun illuminating all.

shloka: तद्बुद्धयस्तदात्मानस्तन्निष्ठास्तत्परायणाः। गच्छन्त्यपुनरावृत्तिं ज्ञाननिर्धूतकल्मषाः॥
translation: Those whose intellect is fixed in That, whose self is merged in That, devoted to That alone—they attain the state of no return, purified by wisdom.

shloka: विद्याविनयसंपन्ने ब्राह्मणे गवि हस्तिनि। शुनि चैव श्वपाके च पण्डिताः समदर्शिनः॥
translation: The wise see with equal vision a learned Brahmin, a cow, an elephant, a dog, and even a dog-eater.

shloka: इहैव तैर्जितः सर्गो येषां साम्ये स्थितं मनः। निर्दोषं हि समं ब्रह्म तस्माद्ब्रह्मणि ते स्थिताः॥
translation: Here in this world, they have conquered rebirth whose minds rest in equality. Brahman is flawless and impartial; therefore, they abide in Brahman.

shloka: न प्रहृष्येत्प्रियं प्राप्य नोद्विजेत्प्राप्य चाप्रियम्। स्थिरबुद्धिरसंमूढो ब्रह्मविद्ब्रह्मणि स्थितः॥
translation: One who neither rejoices in the pleasant nor grieves at the unpleasant, with steady intellect and undeluded—such a knower of Brahman is established in Brahman.

shloka: बाह्यस्पर्शेष्वसक्तात्मा विन्दत्यात्मनि यत्सुखम्। स ब्रह्मयोगयुक्तात्मा सुखमक्षयमश्नुते॥
translation: With the self unattached to external contacts, one finds happiness within. United with Brahman through Yoga, they enjoy imperishable bliss.

shloka: ये हि संस्पर्शजा भोगा दुःखयोनय एव ते। आद्यन्तवन्तः कौन्तेय न तेषु रमते बुधः॥
translation: O Arjuna, pleasures born of sense contacts are only sources of misery. They have a beginning and an end; the wise do not delight in them.

shloka: शक्नोतीहैव यः सोढुं प्राक्शरीरविमोक्षणात्। कामक्रोधोद्भवं वेगं स युक्तः स सुखी नरः॥
translation: One who can withstand the urges of lust and anger before death is a true yogi and a happy person.

shloka: योऽन्तःसुखोऽन्तरारामस्तथान्तर्ज्योतिरेव यः। स योगी ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं ब्रह्मभूतोऽधिगच्छति॥
translation: One who finds happiness within, joy within, and light within—that yogi attains liberation in Brahman, becoming Brahman.

shloka: लभन्ते ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृषयः क्षीणकल्मषाः। छिन्नद्वैधा यतात्मानः सर्वभूतहिते रताः॥
translation: The sages, freed from impurities, cut through doubt, disciplined in self, devoted to the welfare of all beings—they attain liberation in Brahman.

shloka: कामक्रोधवियुक्तानां यतीनां यतचेतसाम्। अभितो ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं वर्तते विदितात्मनाम्॥
translation: Liberation is near for those who are free from desire and anger, who have mastered their thoughts, and who know the Self.

shloka: स्पर्शान्कृत्वा बहिर्बाह्यांश्चक्षुश्चैवान्तरे भ्रुवोः। प्राणापानौ समौ कृत्वा नासाभ्यन्तरचारिणौ॥
translation: Shutting out external sense objects, fixing the gaze between the eyebrows, balancing the inward and outward breaths moving within the nostrils.

shloka: यतेन्द्रियमनोबुद्धिर्मुनिर्मोक्षपरायणः। विगतेच्छाभयक्रोधो यः सदा मुक्त एव सः॥
translation: The sage who controls the senses, mind, and intellect, who is intent on liberation, free from desire, fear, and anger—such a one is ever liberated.

shloka: भोक्तारं यज्ञतपसां सर्वलोकमहेश्वरम्। सुहृदं सर्वभूतानां ज्ञात्वा मां शान्तिमृच्छति॥
translation: Knowing Me as the enjoyer of all sacrifices and austerities, the Supreme Lord of all worlds, and the friend of all beings, one attains peace.

shloka: श्रीभगवानुवाच। अनाश्रितः कर्मफलं कार्यं कर्म करोति यः। स संन्यासी च योगी च न निरग्निर्न चाक्रियः॥
translation: The Lord said: One who performs their duty without dependence on the fruits of action—they are both a renunciant and a yogi, not one who merely abandons rituals or action.

shloka: यं संन्यासमिति प्राहुर्योगं तं विद्धि पाण्डव। न ह्यसंन्यस्तसङ्कल्पो योगी भवति कश्चन॥
translation: O Arjuna, what they call renunciation (Sannyasa), know that to be Yoga. For no one becomes a yogi without relinquishing selfish desires.

shloka: आरुरुक्षोर्मुनेर्योगं कर्म कारणमुच्यते। योगारूढस्य तस्यैव शमः कारणमुच्यते॥
translation: For the sage who seeks to climb the heights of Yoga, action is the means. For that same sage who has attained Yoga, tranquility is the means.

shloka: यदा हि नेन्द्रियार्थेषु न कर्मस्वनुषज्जते। सर्वसङ्कल्पसंन्यासी योगारूढस्तदोच्यते॥
translation: When one is not attached to sense objects or actions, having renounced all desires—then they are said to have ascended Yoga.

shloka: उद्धरेदात्मनात्मानं नात्मानमवसादयेत्। आत्मैव ह्यात्मनो बन्धुरात्मैव रिपुरात्मनः॥
translation: Let the self lift the self by the self; let the self not degrade the self. For the self alone is the friend of the self, and the self alone is the enemy of the self.

shloka: बन्धुरात्मात्मनस्तस्य येनात्मैवात्मना जितः। अनात्मनस्तु शत्रुत्वे वर्तेतात्मैव शत्रुवत्॥
translation: For one who has conquered the self by the self, the self is a friend. But for one who has not, the self remains hostile, like an enemy.

shloka: जितात्मनः प्रशान्तस्य परमात्मा समाहितः। शीतोष्णसुखदुःखेषु तथा मानापमानयोः॥
translation: For the self-controlled and peaceful sage, the Supreme Self is ever present—amid cold and heat, joy and sorrow, honor and disgrace.

shloka: ज्ञानविज्ञानतृप्तात्मा कूटस्थो विजितेन्द्रियः। युक्त इत्युच्यते योगी समलोष्टाश्मकाञ्चनः॥
translation: The yogi is called united when, satisfied with wisdom and realization, unmoved, with senses subdued, they see earth, stone, and gold as the same.

shloka: सुहृन्मित्रार्युदासीनमध्यस्थद्वेष्यबन्धुषु। साधुष्वपि च पापेषु समबुद्धिर्विशिष्यते॥
translation: One who regards well-wishers, friends, foes, neutrals, arbiters, the hateful, relatives, saints, and sinners with equal vision excels.

shloka: योगी युञ्जीत सततमात्मानं रहसि स्थितः। एकाकी यतचित्तात्मा निराशीरपरिग्रहः॥
translation: Let the yogi constantly practice union with the Self, sitting alone in solitude, self-controlled, free from desires and possessions.

shloka: शुचौ देशे प्रतिष्ठाप्य स्थिरमासनमात्मनः। नात्युच्छ्रितं नातिनीचं चैलाजिनकुशोत्तरम्॥
translation: In a clean place, having established a firm seat—neither too high nor too low, covered with cloth, deer-skin, and kusha grass—

shloka: तत्रैकाग्रं मनः कृत्वा यतचित्तेन्द्रियक्रियः। उपविश्यासने युञ्ज्याद्योगमात्मविशुद्धये॥
translation: There, with mind focused and thoughts restrained, let them sit and practice Yoga for the purification of the self.

shloka: समं कायशिरोग्रीवं धारयन्नचलं स्थिरः। संप्रेक्ष्य नासिकाग्रं स्वं दिशश्चानवलोकयन्॥
translation: Holding the body, head, and neck straight and still, gazing steadily at the tip of the nose without looking around.

shloka: प्रशान्तात्मा विगतभीर्ब्रह्मचारिव्रते स्थितः। मनः संयम्य मच्चित्तो युक्त आसीत मत्परः॥
translation: Serene and fearless, firm in the vow of celibacy, with mind subdued and fixed on Me—let them sit in Yoga, absorbed in Me.

shloka: युञ्जन्नेवं सदात्मानं योगी नियतमानसः। शान्तिं निर्वाणपरमां मत्संस्थामधिगच्छति॥
translation: Thus, always uniting the self with discipline, the yogi of controlled mind attains peace—the supreme Nirvana—abiding in Me.

shloka: नात्यश्नतस्तु योगोऽस्ति न चैकान्तमनश्नतः। न चातिस्वप्नशीलस्य जाग्रतो नैव चार्जुन॥
translation: O Arjuna, Yoga is not for one who eats too much or too little, nor for one who sleeps too much or too little.

shloka: युक्ताहारविहारस्य युक्तचेष्टस्य कर्मसु। युक्तस्वप्नावबोधस्य योगो भवति दुःखहा॥
translation: For one who is moderate in eating, recreation, effort, sleep, and wakefulness, Yoga becomes the destroyer of misery.

shloka: यदा विनियतं चित्तमात्मन्येवावतिष्ठते। निःस्पृहः सर्वकामेभ्यो युक्त इत्युच्यते तदा॥
translation: When the disciplined mind rests in the Self alone, free from longing for all desires, then it is said to be united (in Yoga).

shloka: यथा दीपो निवातस्थो नेङ्गते सोपमा स्मृता। योगिनो यतचित्तस्य युञ्जतो योगमात्मनः॥
translation: As a lamp in a windless place does not flicker—such is the simile for the yogi whose mind is subdued and united in the Yoga of the Self.

shloka: यत्रोपरमते चित्तं निरुद्धं योगसेवया। यत्र चैवात्मनात्मानं पश्यन्नात्मनि तुष्यति॥
translation: When the mind, restrained by the practice of Yoga, attains quietude, and when the Self beholds the Self and is satisfied—

shloka: सुखमात्यन्तिकं यत्तद्बुद्धिग्राह्यमतीन्द्रियम्। वेत्ति यत्र न चैवायं स्थितश्चलति तत्त्वतः॥
translation: Then one knows that infinite joy which is beyond the senses and grasped by pure intellect. Established in this reality, one never strays from truth.

shloka: यं लब्ध्वा चापरं लाभं मन्यते नाधिकं ततः। यस्मिन्स्थितो न दुःखेन गुरुणापि विचाल्यते॥
translation: Having gained this, one thinks no other gain superior. Established in this, one is unmoved even by the heaviest sorrow.

shloka: तं विद्याद्दुःखसंयोगवियोगं योगसंज्ञितम्। स निश्चयेन योक्तव्यो योगोऽनिर्विण्णचेतसा॥
translation: Know that disunion from sorrow is called Yoga. This Yoga must be practiced with determination and an unwavering mind.

shloka: सङ्कल्पप्रभवान्कामांस्त्यक्त्वा सर्वानशेषतः। मनसैवेन्द्रियग्रामं विनियम्य समन्ततः॥
translation: Abandoning all desires born of thought, restraining the senses from all sides with the mind—

shloka: शनैः शनैरुपरमेद्बुद्ध्या धृतिगृहीतया। आत्मसंस्थं मनः कृत्वा न किञ्चिदपि चिन्तयेत्॥
translation: Gradually, with the intellect held firm, let one attain tranquility. Fixing the mind in the Self, let them think of nothing else.

shloka: यतो यतो निश्चरति मनश्चञ्चलमस्थिरम्। ततस्ततो नियम्यैतदात्मन्येव वशं नयेत्॥
translation: Whenever the restless, unsteady mind wanders, let one bring it back under the control of the Self.

shloka: प्रशान्तमनसं ह्येनं योगिनं सुखमुत्तमम्। उपैति शान्तरजसं ब्रह्मभूतमकल्मषम्॥
translation: Supreme joy comes to the yogi whose mind is tranquil, whose passions are pacified, who is free from sin and united with Brahman.

shloka: युञ्जन्नेवं सदात्मानं योगी विगतकल्मषः। सुखेन ब्रह्मसंस्पर्शमत्यन्तं सुखमश्नुते॥
translation: Thus, always uniting the self, the sinless yogi easily attains the infinite bliss of union with Brahman.

shloka: सर्वभूतस्थमात्मानं सर्वभूतानि चात्मनि। ईक्षते योगयुक्तात्मा सर्वत्र समदर्शनः॥
translation: The yogi whose self is united in Yoga sees the Self abiding in all beings and all beings in the Self—seeing the same everywhere.

shloka: यो मां पश्यति सर्वत्र सर्वं च मयि पश्यति। तस्याहं न प्रणश्यामि स च मे न प्रणश्यति॥
translation: One who sees Me everywhere and sees all in Me—I am never lost to them, nor are they ever lost to Me.

shloka: सर्वभूतस्थितं यो मां भजत्येकत्वमास्थितः। सर्वथा वर्तमानोऽपि स योगी मयि वर्तते॥
translation: That yogi who, established in oneness, worships Me dwelling in all beings—however they act, they live in Me.

shloka: आत्मौपम्येन सर्वत्र समं पश्यति योऽर्जुन। सुखं वा यदि वा दुःखं स योगी परमो मतः॥
translation: O Arjuna, that yogi is considered the highest who judges happiness or sorrow in all beings by the same standard as applied to oneself.

shloka: अर्जुन उवाच। योऽयं योगस्त्वया प्रोक्तः साम्येन मधुसूदन। एतस्याहं न पश्यामि चञ्चलत्वात्स्थितिं स्थिराम्॥
translation: Arjuna said: O Madhusudana, this Yoga of equanimity You proclaim—I see no stable foundation for it, owing to the restlessness of the mind.

shloka: चञ्चलं हि मनः कृष्ण प्रमाथि बलवद्दृढम्। तस्याहं निग्रहं मन्ये वायोरिव सुदुष्करम्॥
translation: For the mind is restless, turbulent, obstinate, and very strong, O Krishna. To control it seems as difficult as controlling the wind.

shloka: श्रीभगवानुवाच। असंशयं महाबाहो मनो दुर्निग्रहं चलम्। अभ्यासेन तु कौन्तेय वैराग्येण च गृह्यते॥
translation: The Lord said: O mighty-armed Arjuna, undoubtedly the mind is restless and hard to control. But through practice and detachment, it can be mastered.

shloka: असंयतात्मना योगो दुष्प्राप इति मे मतिः। वश्यात्मना तु यतता शक्योऽवाप्तुमुपायतः॥
translation: For one whose self is uncontrolled, Yoga is hard to attain. But for one who strives with a controlled self, it is possible through right means.

shloka: अर्जुन उवाच। अयतिः श्रद्धयोपेतो योगाच्चलितमानसः। अप्राप्य योगसंसिद्धिं कां गतिं कृष्ण गच्छति॥
translation: Arjuna said: O Krishna, what happens to one who begins Yoga with faith but fails to persevere—whose mind wanders away from the path and does not attain perfection?

shloka: कच्चिन्नोभयविभ्रष्टश्छिन्नाभ्रमिव नश्यति। अप्रतिष्ठो महाबाहो विमूढो ब्रह्मणः पथि॥
translation: Do they not perish like a scattered cloud, O mighty-armed one, having failed in both paths (Yoga and worldly life), deluded on the path to Brahman?

shloka: एतन्मे संशयं कृष्ण छेत्तुमर्हस्यशेषतः। त्वदन्यः संशयस्यास्य छेत्ता न ह्युपपद्यते॥
translation: O Krishna, please dispel this doubt of mine completely. For none but You can destroy this doubt.

shloka: श्रीभगवानुवाच। पार्थ नैवेह नामुत्र विनाशस्तस्य विद्यते। न हि कल्याणकृत्कश्चिद्दुर्गतिं तात गच्छति॥
translation: The Lord said: O Arjuna, neither in this world nor the next is there destruction for them. For no doer of good, My son, ever comes to a bad end.

shloka: प्राप्य पुण्यकृतां लोकानुषित्वा शाश्वतीः समाः। शुचीनां श्रीमतां गेहे योगभ्रष्टोऽभिजायते॥
translation: Having attained the worlds of the righteous and dwelt there for countless years, one who fell from Yoga is reborn in a house of the pure and prosperous.

shloka: अथवा योगिनामेव कुले भवति धीमताम्। एतद्धि दुर्लभतरं लोके जन्म यदीदृशम्॥
translation: Or they are born into a family of wise yogis. Such a birth is rare indeed in this world.

shloka: तत्र तं बुद्धिसंयोगं लभते पौर्वदेहिकम्। यतते च ततो भूयः संसिद्धौ कुरुनन्दन॥
translation: There, O Arjuna, they regain the wisdom of their past lives and strive again for perfection.

shloka: पूर्वाभ्यासेन तेनैव ह्रियते ह्यवशोऽपि सः। जिज्ञासुरपि योगस्य शब्दब्रह्मातिवर्तते॥
translation: Even against their will, they are drawn by their past practice. A seeker of Yoga surpasses the rituals of the Vedas.

shloka: प्रयत्नाद्यतमानस्तु योगी संशुद्धकिल्बिषः। अनेकजन्मसंसिद्धस्ततो याति परां गतिम्॥
translation: But the yogi who strives with diligence, purified of sins, perfected through many births, attains the supreme goal.

shloka: तपस्विभ्योऽधिको योगी ज्ञानिभ्योऽपि मतोऽधिकः। कर्मिभ्यश्चाधिको योगी तस्माद्योगी भवार्जुन॥
translation: The yogi is superior to ascetics, superior even to the wise, and superior to ritualists. Therefore, O Arjuna, be a yogi!

shloka: योगिनामपि सर्वेषां मद्गतेनान्तरात्मना। श्रद्धावान्भजते यो मां स मे युक्ततमो मतः॥
translation: And of all yogis, the one who worships Me with faith, their inner self absorbed in Me—they are the most united in Yoga, in My opinion.

shloka: श्रीभगवानुवाच। मय्यासक्तमनाः पार्थ योगं युञ्जन्मदाश्रयः। असंशयं समग्रं मां यथा ज्ञास्यसि तच्छृणु॥
translation: The Lord said: O Arjuna, listen how you can know Me completely, without doubt, by fixing your mind on Me, taking refuge in Me, and practicing Yoga.

shloka: ज्ञानं तेऽहं सविज्ञानमिदं वक्ष्याम्यशेषतः। यज्ज्ञात्वा नेह भूयोऽन्यज्ज्ञातव्यमवशिष्यते॥
translation: I will teach you this knowledge and wisdom in full. Knowing this, nothing else in this world will remain to be known.

shloka: मनुष्याणां सहस्रेषु कश्चिद्यतति सिद्धये। यततामपि सिद्धानां कश्चिन्मां वेत्ति तत्त्वतः॥
translation: Among thousands of men, hardly one strives for perfection. Among those who strive, hardly one knows Me in truth.

shloka: भूमिरापोऽनलो वायुः खं मनो बुद्धिरेव च। अहंकार इतीयं मे भिन्ना प्रकृतिरष्टधा॥
translation: Earth, water, fire, air, space, mind, intellect, and ego—these are the eightfold division of My lower nature.

shloka: अपरेयमितस्त्वन्यां प्रकृतिं विद्धि मे पराम्। जीवभूतां महाबाहो ययेदं धार्यते जगत्॥
translation: O mighty-armed Arjuna, beyond this inferior nature is My higher nature—the life-principle that sustains this universe.

shloka: एतद्योनीनि भूतानि सर्वाणीत्युपधारय। अहं कृत्स्नस्य जगतः प्रभवः प्रलयस्तथा॥
translation: Know that all beings arise from these two natures. I am the origin and dissolution of the entire universe.

shloka: मत्तः परतरं नान्यत्किञ्चिदस्ति धनञ्जय। मयि सर्वमिदं प्रोतं सूत्रे मणिगणा इव॥
translation: O Arjuna, there is nothing higher than Me. Like pearls strung on a thread, all this world is threaded upon Me.

shloka: रसोऽहमप्सु कौन्तेय प्रभास्मि शशिसूर्ययोः। प्रणवः सर्ववेदेषु शब्दः खे पौरुषं नृषु॥
translation: I am the taste in water, O Arjuna, the light in the sun and moon, the sacred syllable Om in all Vedas, sound in space, and valor in men.

shloka: पुण्यो गन्धः पृथिव्यां च तेजश्चास्मि विभावसौ। जीवनं सर्वभूतेषु तपश्चास्मि तपस्विषु॥
translation: I am the pure fragrance in earth, the brilliance in fire, the life in all beings, and the austerity in ascetics.

shloka: बीजं मां सर्वभूतानां विद्धि पार्थ सनातनम्। बुद्धिर्बुद्धिमतामस्मि तेजस्तेजस्विनामहम्॥
translation: O Arjuna, know Me as the eternal seed of all beings. I am the intelligence of the intelligent and the splendor of the splendid.

shloka: बलं बलवतां चाहं कामरागविवर्जितम्। धर्माविरुद्धो भूतेषु कामोऽस्मि भरतर्षभ॥
translation: I am the strength of the strong, free from desire and attachment. In beings, I am desire that is not contrary to dharma, O best of the Bharatas.

shloka: ये चैव सात्त्विका भावा राजसास्तामसाश्च ये। मत्त एवेति तान्विद्धि न त्वहं तेषु ते मयि॥
translation: Know that the states of being—sattva (goodness), rajas (passion), and tamas (ignorance)—all arise from Me. But I am not in them; they are in Me.

shloka: त्रिभिर्गुणमयैर्भावैरेभिः सर्वमिदं जगत्। मोहितं नाभिजानाति मामेभ्यः परमव्ययम्॥
translation: Deluded by these three modes of nature, the world fails to recognize Me, who am beyond them and imperishable.

shloka: दैवी ह्येषा गुणमयी मम माया दुरत्यया। मामेव ये प्रपद्यन्ते मायामेतां तरन्ति ते॥
translation: This divine illusion of Mine, made of the modes of nature, is hard to overcome. But those who surrender to Me alone cross beyond it.

shloka: न मां दुष्कृतिनो मूढाः प्रपद्यन्ते नराधमाः। माययापहृतज्ञाना आसुरं भावमाश्रिताः॥
translation: The evil-doers, the deluded, the lowest of men, deprived of wisdom by illusion, do not surrender to Me. They are devoted to demonic ways.

shloka: चतुर्विधा भजन्ते मां जनाः सुकृतिनोऽर्जुन। आर्तो जिज्ञासुरर्थार्थी ज्ञानी च भरतर्षभ॥
translation: O Arjuna, four kinds of virtuous people worship Me: the distressed, the seeker of knowledge, the seeker of wealth, and the wise, O best of the Bharatas.

shloka: तेषां ज्ञानी नित्ययुक्त एकभक्तिर्विशिष्यते। प्रियो हि ज्ञानिनोऽत्यर्थमहं स च मम प्रियः॥
translation: Among them, the wise, ever united with Me and devoted to Me alone, excels. For I am exceedingly dear to the wise, and they are dear to Me.

shloka: उदाराः सर्व एवैते ज्ञानी त्वात्मैव मे मतम्। आस्थितः स हि युक्तात्मा मामेवानुत्तमां गतिम्॥
translation: All these devotees are noble, but I regard the wise as My very Self. For they, steadfast in mind, are established in Me alone as the supreme goal.

shloka: बहूनां जन्मनामन्ते ज्ञानवान्मां प्रपद्यते। वासुदेवः सर्वमिति स महात्मा सुदुर्लभः॥
translation: After many births, the wise man realizes Me as the all-pervading Vasudeva. Such a great soul is rare.

shloka: कामैस्तैस्तैर्हृतज्ञानाः प्रपद्यन्तेऽन्यदेवताः। तं तं नियममास्थाय प्रकृत्या नियताः स्वया॥
translation: Those whose wisdom is stolen by desires worship other gods, following the rites of their own natures.

shloka: यो यो यां यां तनुं भक्तः श्रद्धयार्चितुमिच्छति। तस्य तस्याचलां श्रद्धां तामेव विदधाम्यहम्॥
translation: Whatever form a devotee seeks to worship with faith, I strengthen that very faith in them.

shloka: स तया श्रद्धया युक्तस्तस्याराधनमीहते। लभते च ततः कामान्मयैव विहितान्हि तान्॥
translation: Endowed with that faith, they worship that form and obtain their desires, which are granted by Me alone.

shloka: अन्तवत्तु फलं तेषां तद्भवत्यल्पमेधसाम्। देवान्देवयजो यान्ति मद्भक्ता यान्ति मामपि॥
translation: But the fruits of those with little understanding are limited. Worshippers of the gods go to the gods, while My devotees come to Me.

shloka: अव्यक्तं व्यक्तिमापन्नं मन्यन्ते मामबुद्धयः। परं भावमजानन्तो ममाव्ययमनुत्तमम्॥
translation: The unintelligent think of Me, the Unmanifest, as having taken form, not knowing My higher nature—imperishable and supreme.

shloka: नाहं प्रकाशः सर्वस्य योगमायासमावृतः। मूढोऽयं नाभिजानाति लोको मामजमव्ययम्॥
translation: Veiled by My divine power (Yoga Maya), I am not revealed to all. This deluded world knows Me not—the unborn, the imperishable.

shloka: वेदाहं समतीतानि वर्तमानानि चार्जुन। भविष्याणि च भूतानि मां तु वेद न कश्चन॥
translation: O Arjuna, I know the past, present, and future of all beings. But no one knows Me.

shloka: इच्छाद्वेषसमुत्थेन द्वन्द्वमोहेन भारत। सर्वभूतानि संमोहं सर्गे यान्ति परन्तप॥
translation: O Arjuna, all beings are born into delusion, overcome by the dualities of desire and aversion.

shloka: येषां त्वन्तगतं पापं जनानां पुण्यकर्मणाम्। ते द्वन्द्वमोहनिर्मुक्ता भजन्ते मां दृढव्रताः॥
translation: But those whose sins have been destroyed by virtuous deeds, freed from duality’s delusion, worship Me with firm resolve.

shloka: जरामरणमोक्षाय मामाश्रित्य यतन्ति ये। ते ब्रह्म तद्विदुः कृत्स्नमध्यात्मं कर्म चाखिलम्॥
translation: Those who strive for liberation from old age and death, taking refuge in Me, come to know Brahman, the individual self, and all action.

shloka: साधिभूताधिदैवं मां साधियज्ञं च ये विदुः। प्रयाणकालेऽपि च मां ते विदुर्युक्तचेतसः॥
translation: Those who know Me as the Lord of all existence, the deity of all deities, and the sacrifice of all sacrifices, remember Me even at the time of death.

shloka: अर्जुन उवाच। किं तद्ब्रह्म किमध्यात्मं किं कर्म पुरुषोत्तम। अधिभूतं च किं प्रोक्तमधिदैवं किमुच्यते॥
translation: Arjuna said: O Supreme Person, what is Brahman? What is the individual self? What is action? What is the material manifestation? And what are the celestial controllers?

shloka: अधियज्ञः कथं कोऽत्र देहेऽस्मिन्मधुसूदन। प्रयाणकाले च कथं ज्ञेयोऽसि नियतात्मभिः॥
translation: Who is the Lord of sacrifice, and how does He dwell in the body, O Madhusudana? And how at the time of death are You to be known by those of steadfast mind?

shloka: श्रीभगवानुवाच। अक्षरं ब्रह्म परमं स्वभावोऽध्यात्ममुच्यते। भूतभावोद्भवकरो विसर्गः कर्मसंज्ञितः॥
translation: The Lord said: The supreme indestructible reality is Brahman. The individual self is called Adhyatma. Action that creates beings is termed Karma.

shloka: अधिभूतं क्षरो भावः पुरुषश्चाधिदैवतम्। अधियज्ञोऽहमेवात्र देहे देहभृतां वर॥
translation: The perishable material manifestation is Adhibhuta. The cosmic spirit is Adhidaiva. And I Myself, O Arjuna, am the Lord of sacrifice (Adhiyajña) in this body.

shloka: अन्तकाले च मामेव स्मरन्मुक्त्वा कलेवरम्। यः प्रयाति स मद्भावं याति नास्त्यत्र संशयः॥
translation: Whoever, at the time of death, remembers Me alone and leaves the body—they attain My nature. Of this there is no doubt.

shloka: यं यं वापि स्मरन्भावं त्यजत्यन्ते कलेवरम्। तं तमेवैति कौन्तेय सदा तद्भावभावितः॥
translation: O Arjuna, whatever state of being one remembers at the time of death, that state they attain, having been absorbed in it always.

shloka: तस्मात्सर्वेषु कालेषु मामनुस्मर युध्य च। मय्यर्पितमनोबुद्धिर्मामेवैष्यस्यसंशयः॥
translation: Therefore, remember Me at all times and fight. With mind and intellect surrendered to Me, you will surely come to Me.

shloka: अभ्यासयोगयुक्तेन चेतसा नान्यगामिना। परमं पुरुषं दिव्यं याति पार्थानुचिन्तयन्॥
translation: O Arjuna, by meditating on the Supreme Divine Person with a mind disciplined through practice and unwavering in devotion, one attains Him.

shloka: कविं पुराणमनुशासितारमणोरणीयांसमनुस्मरेद्यः। सर्वस्य धातारमचिन्त्यरूपमादित्यवर्णं तमसः परस्तात्॥
translation: One should meditate on the Omniscient, Ancient, Ruler, subtler than the atom, Sustainer of all, beyond thought, resplendent like the sun, and beyond darkness.

shloka: प्रयाणकाले मनसाऽचलेन भक्त्या युक्तो योगबलेन चैव। भ्रुवोर्मध्ये प्राणमावेश्य सम्यक् स तं परं पुरुषमुपैति दिव्यम्॥
translation: At the time of death, with unshaken mind, fortified by devotion and the power of Yoga, fixing the life-force between the eyebrows, one attains that supreme Divine Person.

shloka: यदक्षरं वेदविदो वदन्ति विशन्ति यद्यतयो वीतरागाः। यदिच्छन्तो ब्रह्मचर्यं चरन्ति तत्ते पदं संग्रहेण प्रवक्ष्ये॥
translation: I shall briefly explain that imperishable goal which the knowers of the Vedas declare, which seekers enter through celibacy, and desiring which they practice discipline.

shloka: सर्वद्वाराणि संयम्य मनो हृदि निरुध्य च। मूर्ध्न्याधायात्मनः प्राणमास्थितो योगधारणाम्॥
translation: Closing all the gates of the senses, fixing the mind in the heart, and drawing the life-breath to the forehead, one establishes oneself in Yogic concentration.

shloka: ओमित्येकाक्षरं ब्रह्म व्याहरन्मामनुस्मरन्। यः प्रयाति त्यजन्देहं स याति परमां गतिम्॥
translation: Chanting the single syllable 'Om'—Brahman in sound—and remembering Me, whoever departs the body attains the supreme goal.

shloka: अनन्यचेताः सततं यो मां स्मरति नित्यशः। तस्याहं सुलभः पार्थ नित्ययुक्तस्य योगिनः॥
translation: O Arjuna, I am easily attained by the yogi who constantly remembers Me with undivided mind.

shloka: मामुपेत्य पुनर्जन्म दुःखालयमशाश्वतम्। नाप्नुवन्ति महात्मानः संसिद्धिं परमां गताः॥
translation: The great souls who attain Me are no longer subject to rebirth in this temporary world of misery, having reached the highest perfection.

shloka: आब्रह्मभुवनाल्लोकाः पुनरावर्तिनोऽर्जुन। मामुपेत्य तु कौन्तेय पुनर्जन्म न विद्यते॥
translation: O Arjuna, all worlds, including the abode of Brahma, are subject to rebirth. But one who reaches Me never takes birth again.

shloka: सहस्रयुगपर्यन्तमहर्यद्ब्रह्मणो विदुः। रात्रिं युगसहस्रान्तां तेऽहोरात्रविदो जनाः॥
translation: Those who know the day of Brahma, lasting a thousand ages, and his night, ending after another thousand ages—they know day and night.

shloka: अव्यक्ताद्व्यक्तयः सर्वाः प्रभवन्त्यहरागमे। रात्र्यागमे प्रलीयन्ते तत्रैवाव्यक्तसंज्ञके॥
translation: At the dawn of Brahma's day, all beings emerge from the unmanifest. At the fall of night, they merge back into the unmanifest.

shloka: भूतग्रामः स एवायं भूत्वा भूत्वा प्रलीयते। रात्र्यागमेऽवशः पार्थ प्रभवत्यहरागमे॥
translation: O Arjuna, this multitude of beings, born again and again, dissolves helplessly at nightfall and emerges at daybreak.

shloka: परस्तस्मात्तु भावोऽन्योऽव्यक्तोऽव्यक्तात्सनातनः। यः स सर्वेषु भूतेषु नश्यत्सु न विनश्यति॥
translation: But beyond this unmanifest is another eternal, unmanifest reality—the Supreme, which does not perish even when all beings perish.

shloka: अव्यक्तोऽक्षर इत्युक्तस्तमाहुः परमां गतिम्। यं प्राप्य न निवर्तन्ते तद्धाम परमं मम॥
translation: That unmanifest, imperishable state is called the Supreme Goal. Attaining it, none return. That is My supreme abode.

shloka: पुरुषः स परः पार्थ भक्त्या लभ्यस्त्वनन्यया। यस्यान्तःस्थानि भूतानि येन सर्वमिदं ततम्॥
translation: O Arjuna, the Supreme Person is attained by unwavering devotion. Though He dwells within all beings, He pervades and sustains all.

shloka: यत्र काले त्वनावृत्तिमावृत्तिं चैव योगिनः। प्रयाता यान्ति तं कालं वक्ष्यामि भरतर्षभ॥
translation: O Arjuna, I shall now explain the paths of light and darkness, which yogis take at death, never to return or to return.

shloka: अग्निर्ज्योतिरहः शुक्लः षण्मासा उत्तरायणम्। तत्र प्रयाता गच्छन्ति ब्रह्म ब्रह्मविदो जनाः॥
translation: Those who know Brahman and depart in light (fire, brightness, day, the bright fortnight, the sun’s northern course) attain Brahman.

shloka: धूमो रात्रिस्तथा कृष्णः षण्मासा दक्षिणायनम्। तत्र चान्द्रमसं ज्योतिर्योगी प्राप्य निवर्तते॥
translation: But those who depart in darkness (smoke, night, the dark fortnight, the sun’s southern course) reach the lunar light and return.

shloka: शुक्लकृष्णे गती ह्येते जगतः शाश्वते मते। एकया यात्यनावृत्तिमन्ययावर्तते पुनः॥
translation: These two paths—light and darkness—are eternal. By one, one attains liberation; by the other, one returns.

shloka: नैते सृती पार्थ जानन्योगी मुह्यति कश्चन। तस्मात्सर्वेषु कालेषु योगयुक्तो भवार्जुन॥
translation: O Arjuna, no yogi who knows these two paths is deluded. Therefore, be steadfast in Yoga at all times.

shloka: वेदेषु यज्ञेषु तपःसु चैव दानेषु यत्पुण्यफलं प्रदिष्टम्। अत्येति तत्सर्वमिदं विदित्वा योगी परं स्थानमुपैति चाद्यम्॥
translation: The yogi who knows this surpasses all rewards of Vedic study, sacrifice, austerity, and charity, and attains the supreme primal abode.

shloka: श्रीभगवानुवाच। इदं तु ते गुह्यतमं प्रवक्ष्याम्यनसूयवे। ज्ञानं विज्ञानसहितं यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात्॥
translation: The Lord said: To you who do not envy, I shall reveal this most secret wisdom, combined with realization, knowing which you will be freed from misfortune.

shloka: राजविद्या राजगुह्यं पवित्रमिदमुत्तमम्। प्रत्यक्षावगमं धर्म्यं सुसुखं कर्तुमव्ययम्॥
translation: This is the sovereign science, the sovereign secret, the supreme purifier, directly realizable, righteous, joyful, and imperishable.

shloka: अश्रद्दधानाः पुरुषा धर्मस्यास्य परन्तप। अप्राप्य मां निवर्तन्ते मृत्युसंसारवर्त्मनि॥
translation: O subduer of foes, those who lack faith in this Dharma, failing to attain Me, return to the path of death and rebirth.

shloka: मया ततमिदं सर्वं जगदव्यक्तमूर्तिना। मत्स्थानि सर्वभूतानि न चाहं तेष्ववस्थितः॥
translation: All this world is pervaded by Me in My unmanifest form. All beings abide in Me, but I do not abide in them.

shloka: न च मत्स्थानि भूतानि पश्य मे योगमैश्वरम्। भूतभृन्न च भूतस्थो ममात्मा भूतभावनः॥
translation: And yet, beings do not abide in Me—behold My divine mystery! Though I sustain all beings and give them life, My Self is not dependent on them.

shloka: यथाकाशस्थितो नित्यं वायुः सर्वत्रगो महान्। तथा सर्वाणि भूतानि मत्स्थानीत्युपधारय॥
translation: As the mighty wind, moving everywhere, eternally dwells in space, so all beings dwell in Me—understand this!

shloka: सर्वभूतानि कौन्तेय प्रकृतिं यान्ति मामिकाम्। कल्पक्षये पुनस्तानि कल्पादौ विसृजाम्यहम्॥
translation: O Arjuna, at the end of a cycle, all beings merge into My nature, and at the beginning of the next, I send them forth again.

shloka: प्रकृतिं स्वामवष्टभ्य विसृजामि पुनः पुनः। भूतग्राममिमं कृत्स्नमवशं प्रकृतेर्वशात्॥
translation: Taking hold of My own nature, I create these multitudes of beings again and again, helpless under the sway of Prakriti.

shloka: न च मां तानि कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनञ्जय। उदासीनवदासीनमसक्तं तेषु कर्मसु॥
translation: O Arjuna, these actions do not bind Me, for I remain detached, like a spectator, unattached to those works.

shloka: मयाध्यक्षेण प्रकृतिः सूयते सचराचरम्। हेतुनानेन कौन्तेय जगद्विपरिवर्तते॥
translation: Under My supervision, Prakriti gives birth to all moving and unmoving beings. O Arjuna, because of this, the world revolves.

shloka: अवजानन्ति मां मूढा मानुषीं तनुमाश्रितम्। परं भावमजानन्तो मम भूतमहेश्वरम्॥
translation: Fools disregard Me when I assume a human form, not knowing My supreme nature as the Lord of all beings.

shloka: मोघाशा मोघकर्माणो मोघज्ञाना विचेतसः। राक्षसीमासुरीं चैव प्रकृतिं मोहिनीं श्रिताः॥
translation: Their hopes vain, their actions vain, their knowledge vain, their senseless minds—they are deluded by the deceptive, demonic, and destructive nature.

shloka: महात्मानस्तु मां पार्थ दैवीं प्रकृतिमाश्रिताः। भजन्त्यनन्यमनसो ज्ञात्वा भूतादिमव्ययम्॥
translation: But the noble souls, O Arjuna, who take refuge in My divine nature, worship Me single-mindedly, knowing Me as the imperishable source of all beings.

shloka: सततं कीर्तयन्तो मां यतन्तश्च दृढव्रताः। नमस्यन्तश्च मां भक्त्या नित्ययुक्ता उपासते॥
translation: Always chanting My glories, striving with firm resolve, bowing down to Me with devotion, they worship Me with unwavering discipline.

shloka: ज्ञानयज्ञेन चाप्यन्ये यजन्तो मामुपासते। एकत्वेन पृथक्त्वेन बहुधा विश्वतोमुखम्॥
translation: Others worship Me through the sacrifice of knowledge, seeing Me as One, as many, or as the universal form facing all directions.

shloka: अहं क्रतुरहं यज्ञः स्वधाहमहमौषधम्। मन्त्रोऽहमहमेवाज्यमहमग्निरहं हुतम्॥
translation: I am the ritual, I am the sacrifice, I am the offering, I am the herb, I am the mantra, I am the ghee, I am the fire, and I am the oblation.

shloka: पिताहमस्य जगतो माता धाता पितामहः। वेद्यं पवित्रमोङ्कार ऋक्साम यजुरेव च॥
translation: I am the father, mother, sustainer, and grandfather of this universe. I am the object of knowledge, the purifier, the syllable Om, and the Rig, Sama, and Yajur Vedas.

shloka: गतिर्भर्ता प्रभुः साक्षी निवासः शरणं सुहृत्। प्रभवः प्रलयः स्थानं निधानं बीजमव्ययम्॥
translation: I am the goal, the sustainer, the master, the witness, the abode, the refuge, the friend, the origin, the dissolution, the foundation, the treasure-house, and the imperishable seed.

shloka: तपाम्यहमहं वर्षं निगृह्णाम्युत्सृजामि च। अमृतं चैव मृत्युश्च सदसच्चाहमर्जुन॥
translation: I give heat, I withhold and send forth rain. I am immortality and death, O Arjuna. I am existence and non-existence.

shloka: त्रैविद्या मां सोमपाः पूतपापा यज्ञैरिष्ट्वा स्वर्गतिं प्रार्थयन्ते। ते पुण्यमासाद्य सुरेन्द्रलोकमश्नन्ति दिव्यान्दिवि देवभोगान्॥
translation: Those who study the Vedas, drink the Soma juice, and worship Me with sacrifices seek the heavenly realms. Purified of sins, they attain Indra’s abode and enjoy celestial pleasures.

shloka: ते तं भुक्त्वा स्वर्गलोकं विशालं क्षीणे पुण्ये मर्त्यलोकं विशन्ति। एवं त्रयीधर्ममनुप्रपन्ना गतागतं कामकामा लभन्ते॥
translation: Having enjoyed the vast heavens, their merits exhausted, they return to the mortal world. Thus, following the Vedic rites but still craving pleasures, they come and go.

shloka: अनन्याश्चिन्तयन्तो मां ये जनाः पर्युपासते। तेषां नित्याभियुक्तानां योगक्षेमं वहाम्यहम्॥
translation: But to those who worship Me alone, thinking of no other, to those ever united with Me, I carry what they lack and preserve what they have.

shloka: येऽप्यन्यदेवताभक्ता यजन्ते श्रद्धयाऽन्विताः। तेऽपि मामेव कौन्तेय यजन्त्यविधिपूर्वकम्॥
translation: O Arjuna, even devotees of other deities who worship with faith are actually worshipping Me, though not according to the true ordinance.

shloka: अहं हि सर्वयज्ञानां भोक्ता च प्रभुरेव च। न तु मामभिजानन्ति तत्त्वेनातश्च्यवन्ति ते॥
translation: For I am the enjoyer and Lord of all sacrifices. But they do not know Me in truth, and thus they fall.

shloka: यान्ति देवव्रता देवान्पितृ़न्यान्ति पितृव्रताः। भूतानि यान्ति भूतेज्या यान्ति मद्याजिनोऽपि माम्॥
translation: Worshippers of the gods go to the gods; worshippers of ancestors go to the ancestors; worshippers of spirits go to the spirits; but My devotees come to Me.

shloka: पत्रं पुष्पं फलं तोयं यो मे भक्त्या प्रयच्छति। तदहं भक्त्युपहृतमश्नामि प्रयतात्मनः॥
translation: If one offers Me with devotion a leaf, a flower, a fruit, or even water, I accept that offering of the pure-hearted.

shloka: यत्करोषि यदश्नासि यज्जुहोषि ददासि यत्। यत्तपस्यसि कौन्तेय तत्कुरुष्व मदर्पणम्॥
translation: O Arjuna, whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you offer in sacrifice, whatever you give, whatever austerity you practice—do it as an offering to Me.

shloka: शुभाशुभफलैरेवं मोक्ष्यसे कर्मबन्धनैः। संन्यासयोगयुक्तात्मा विमुक्तो मामुपैष्यसि॥
translation: Thus freed from the bondage of actions, both good and bad, your soul united with the Yoga of renunciation, you will come to Me.

shloka: समोऽहं सर्वभूतेषु न मे द्वेष्योऽस्ति न प्रियः। ये भजन्ति तु मां भक्त्या मयि ते तेषु चाप्यहम्॥
translation: I am equal to all beings; none is hateful or dear to Me. But those who worship Me with devotion are in Me, and I am in them.

shloka: अपि चेत्सुदुराचारो भजते मामनन्यभाक्। साधुरेव स मन्तव्यः सम्यग्व्यवसितो हि सः॥
translation: Even if the vilest sinner worships Me with exclusive devotion, they are to be considered righteous, for they have resolved rightly.

shloka: क्षिप्रं भवति धर्मात्मा शश्वच्छान्तिं निगच्छति। कौन्तेय प्रतिजानीहि न मे भक्तः प्रणश्यति॥
translation: O Arjuna, declare boldly that My devotee never perishes. Quickly they become righteous and attain lasting peace.

shloka: मां हि पार्थ व्यपाश्रित्य येऽपि स्युः पापयोनयः। स्त्रियो वैश्यास्तथा शूद्रास्तेऽपि यान्ति परां गतिम्॥
translation: O Arjuna, even those born in sinful wombs—women, vaishyas, or shudras—by taking refuge in Me, attain the supreme goal.

shloka: किं पुनर्ब्राह्मणाः पुण्या भक्ता राजर्षयस्तथा। अनित्यमसुखं लोकमिमं प्राप्य भजस्व माम्॥
translation: How much more then the righteous brahmins, devotees, and royal sages! Having obtained this transient and joyless world, worship Me.

shloka: मन्मना भव मद्भक्तो मद्याजी मां नमस्कुरु। मामेवैष्यसि युक्त्वैवमात्मानं मत्परायणः॥
translation: Fix your mind on Me, be devoted to Me, worship Me, bow to Me. Thus uniting yourself with Me, making Me your supreme goal, you will surely come to Me.

shloka: श्रीभगवानुवाच। भूय एव महाबाहो शृणु मे परमं वचः। यत्तेऽहं प्रीयमाणाय वक्ष्यामि हितकाम्यया॥
translation: The Lord said: O mighty-armed Arjuna, listen again to My supreme word, which I shall speak to you for your benefit and because you delight Me.

shloka: न मे विदुः सुरगणाः प्रभवं न महर्षयः। अहमादिर्हि देवानां महर्षीणां च सर्वशः॥
translation: Neither the hosts of gods nor the great sages know My origin, for I am the source of all gods and sages in every way.

shloka: यो मामजमनादिं च वेत्ति लोकमहेश्वरम्। असंमूढः स मर्त्येषु सर्वपापैः प्रमुच्यते॥
translation: One who knows Me as unborn, beginningless, and the Supreme Lord of the world is undeluded among mortals and freed from all sins.

shloka: बुद्धिर्ज्ञानमसंमोहः क्षमा सत्यं दमः शमः। सुखं दुःखं भवोऽभावो भयं चाभयमेव च॥
